title: HMS Puckeridge
text:
HMS "Puckeridge" was a of the <a href="Royal%20Navy">Royal Navy</a> and first and so far only warship to bear the Name. The vessel was ordered on 4 September 1939 as part of the <a href="War%20Emergency%20Programme%20destroyers%23Design%20changes%20%28World%20War%20II%29">1939 wartime emergency program</a>. She was laid down on 1 January 1940 at the <a href="J.%20Samuel%20White">J. Samuel White</a> yard, <a href="East%20Cowes">East Cowes</a>, on the <a href="Isle%20of%20Wight">Isle of Wight</a>, launched on 6 March 1941 and commissioned on 30 July 1941.
"Puckeridge" was one of 33, <a href="Hunt%20class%20destroyer%23Type%20II">Type II Hunt</a> <a href="Escort%20destroyer">Escort Destroyers</a>. The hulls of this second batch had an extra section and an increased beam which gave stability for a third <a href="QF%204%20inch%20Mk%20XVI%20naval%20gun">twin 4" AA gun</a> as originally designed and additional storage for depth charges. The class were named after British <a href="fox%20hunting">fox</a> and <a href="Deer%20hunting%23United_Kingdom%20and%20Republic%20of%20Ireland">stag</a> hunts, in this case, the <a href="Puckeridge%20Hunt">Puckeridge Hunt</a>, based in <a href="East%20Anglia">East Anglia</a>.
Service history.
Home Fleet.
In December 1941 "Puckeridge" was attached to the Home Fleet. On 13 December she was attacked by aircraft off the <a href="Pembrokeshire">Pembroke</a> coast and was hit by a bomb on her <a href="Quarterdeck">Quarterdeck</a> which caused an explosion in her aft 4-inch magazine. 18 ratings were killed and 20 injured and her aft 4-inch gun was lost overboard. Damage control dealt with fires and the ship settled by the stern with the quarterdeck awash. When propulsion was restored, "Puckeridge" sailed to <a href="Milford%20Haven">Milford Haven</a> steering just by engines, before being towed to <a href="HM%20Dockyard">HM Dockyard</a>, <a href="Pembroke%20Dock">Pembroke Dock</a> for repair and was eventually re-commissioned on 10 July 1942.
Western Approaches.
After 3 months working-up and escorting Minelaying operations from <a href="Scapa%20Flow">Scapa Flow</a> "Puckeridge" was deployed in the <a href="Western%20Approaches">Western Approaches</a> as a convoy escort. On 5 October she joined convoy WS23 then Escorted troopships Bergensfjord and Leopoldville from <a href="Freetown">Freetown</a> to <a href="Gibraltar">Gibraltar</a>.
Operation Torch.
On 8 November 1942 "Puckeridge" supported landing operations at <a href="Oran">Oran</a> during <a href="Operation%20Torch">Operation Torch</a> and later searched for survivors of Dutch destroyer <a href="HNLMS%20Isaac%20Sweers%20%281940%29">HNLMS Isaac Sweers</a> sunk by <a href="German%20submarine%20U-431">German submarine U-431</a> north-west of <a href="Algiers">Algiers</a>.
1943 and fate.
"Puckeridge" undertook patrols and escorting convoys from Gibraltar until 6 June 1943, when she was mobilised for <a href="Operation%20HUSKY">Operation Husky</a>, the Allied landing in Sicily, Italy, and was assigned to the East support force.
On 5 July she was assigned to protect convoy KMS18 convoy departing from Tunisia, and on 6 August "Puckeridge" escorted two passenger liners, and , from Gibraltar to <a href="Malta">Malta</a>.
Fate
On 6 September 1943, around 20:15 hours "Puckeridge" was hit by two of four torpedoes fired by the <a href="German%20submarine%20U-617">German submarine U-617</a> commanded by <a href="Albrecht%20Brandi">Albrecht Brandi</a> and sank 40 nautical miles east of Gibraltar. The two hits aft detonated her magazine and she sank in 8 minutes. 129 men were rescued and 62 men were lost with the ship. Some survivors were rescued by a Spanish <a href="mercantile">mercantile</a> ship and avoided internment by attracting the attention of a naval patrol craft which took them back to Gibraltar. U-617 was later ran aground and abandoned on 12 September 1943 near <a href="Melilla">Melilla</a> after an air attack by <a href="RAF">RAF</a> <a href="Vickers%20Wellington">Wellington</a> bombers from <a href="No.%20179%20Squadron%20RAF">179 Squadron</a>.
"Puckeridge" lies at a depth of 1000 metres at and is a controlled site under the <a href="Protection%20of%20Military%20Remains%20Act">Protection of Military Remains Act</a>.
